name: o-toluic_acid
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.

name: o-toluic_acid
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.
Reason: The benzene ring is the basic structural unit which has a known melting point of 5.5°C. The addition of a methyl group (CH3-) increases this value due to the slight increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces, this can be estimated to be an increase of about +20°C. The carboxylic acid group (-COOH) substantially increases the melting point because of the strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding it introduces. Typically, a carboxylic acid group contributes an increase of about +80°C. Since o-toluic acid has both of these groups ortho to each other, there may be a slight steric hindrance that prevents effective intermolecular interactions from reaching their full potential, which might marginally lower the melting point by about -0.5°C compared to what one might expect if the groups were not interacting
